div.p: 1. The current word for concentrating one's attention or one's actions in one direction is zhuān 專／摶.
2. Níng 凝 refers to the concentration of abstract or "metaphysical" substances.
3. Yī 一 and yī 壹 emphasise the uniqueness of what is being concentrated on.
4. Xíng 行 and fú 服 "devote oneself completely to" focusses on action rather than thought as the field of concentration.
5. Jī 積 emphasises the cumulative results of concentration.
集中 is the current modern word for concentration.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

entry.def: Yī 一 and yī 壹 emphasise the uniqueness of what is being concentrated on.

sense.def: concentrate on one thing; be single-minded
concentrate uniquely on
concentrate!

concentrate 壹志 "concentrate the mind"
meditation

(teaching, etc.) of concentration

sense.def: in a focussed proper way
concentrate on

cause to be (properly) concentrated

concentrate on
focus (one's mind); concentrate on

entry.def: Xíng 行and fú 服 "devote oneself completely to" focusses on action rather than thought as the field of concentration.

sense.def: devote oneself to, be preoccupied by
concentrate on

entry.def: Jī 積 emphasises the cumulative results of concentration.

sense.def: concentrate (strength or effort) on
concentrate 聚精會神
orientate oneself towards, feel at home in (in transferred sense); take one's stand in; practise or exercise (a virtue); settle for
focus on

entry.def: Causing oneself to have a unified mind.

sense.def: BUDDH: the One Mind (which comprises everything); the notion of One Mind of the early Chán School is usually based on the discussion in QIXINLUN
with one's whole heart > whole-heartedly, single-mindedly, (GERMAN von ganzer Seele, mit Herz und Seele)
BUDDH: skr. samādhi; state of meditative absorption
BUDDH: cultivate/exercise and focus (one's mind) > concentrate
BUDDH: stop the mind (this refers to a traditional meditation practice)
enter into a trance of concentration; enter samādhi
concentrate on one thing
find complete peace of mind
BUDDH: constantly maintain, remain focussed on; continue to concentrate on
BUDDH: engage in quiet contemplation/meditation [mod. CH]
one-sided concentration; one-dimensionality
concentrate one's thoughts on
arrested>focussed observation> spiritual concentration as a Buddhist method of self-cultivation

bibl.title: 佛教語大辭典 Bukkyōgo daijiten Encyclopedic Dictionary of Buddhist Terms

sense.def: BUDDH: concentration, meditative absorption; skr. samādhi
turn one's attention to; concentrate on; be careful about (with the object marked by a coverbal construction)
BUDDH: concentration, meditative absorption (see the standard terms dìng 定 and sānmèi 三昧); SANSKRIT samādhi
in a concentrated way; concentrating one's mind
BUDDH: concentration, meditative absorption (see the standard terms dìng 定 and sānmèi 三昧); SANSKRIT samādhi
BUDDH: concentration of the mind where there is no absolute freedom from passions; SANSKRIT kāma-dhyāna, kāma-avacara-samādhi

note.p: " The"concentration of cessation." An extremely deep sam$adhi where the activities of the mind are completely extinguished. In Abhidharmako$xa theory, it is one of the fourteen elements not concomitant with mind, and in Consciousness-only theory, it is one of the twenty-four elements not concomitant with mind. When this concentration is practiced, the mano-consciousness is also extinguished. Then the practitioner can be reborn into the Highest Heaven. Since this concentration has the power to extinguish mental functions in the mano consciousness, it is said to be the concentration practiced by sages. Since low-level practitioners and non-Buddhists are afraid to extinguish their egos, they do not enter this concentration of complete extinction. It is also called the 'concentration of extinguishing feeling and perception.' The seeds of 'disgusted mind' are established on the basis of this concentration."

sense.def: BUDDH: attainment of cessation, mental state of absorption where all functions of the mind come to a complete halt; skr. nirodha-samāpatti
BUDDH: concentrations in the realm of form (state of mind free from passions, but accompanied by a sensation of physical well-being); SANSKRIT rūpa-avacara-samādhi

bibl.title: 佛光大辭典 Fóguāng dàcídiǎn The Foguang Dictionary of Buddhism

sense.def: BUDDH: kind of samādhi: Wind Samādhi (in which one generates a violent wind which tears one's body to pieces; see also fēngfènxùn sānmèi 風奮迅三昧)

sense.def: BUDDH: One-Practice samādhi (in LENGQIE SHIZI JI defined as 'fixing one's awareness on ultimate reality; related to the term yīxiàng 一相)
BUDDH: kind of samādhi; see 無所有處定
BUDDH: the four (meditative) attainments of non-form; SANSKRIT catur-ārūpya-samāpatti; PALI catasso āruppa-samāpattiyo
concentrate
BUDDH: onepointedness of mind > concentration; SANSKRIT citta-ekāgratā; PALI citta ssa ekaggatā
BUDDH: a kind of contemplative concentration, the Sūraṃgama-saṃādhi
DELETE

bibl.title: 佛教語大辭典 Bukkyōgo daijiten Encyclopedic Dictionary of Buddhist Terms

sense.def: BUDDH: kind of meditative absorption: samādhi of no-mark, formless samādhi (this refers to a state of concentration where all differences of forms/features typical for constituents of extistence are transcended); skr. animitthaḥ-cetaḥ-samādhiḥ

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Chinese Buddhist Terms

note.p: 無證: "Without strive, debate, or contradiction; passionlessness; abiding in the 'empty' of spiritual life without debate, or without striving with others."

sense.def: BUDDH: No-conflict samādhi (a state of mind in which there is no opposition to others, being one of the characterstics of 'the foremost among men'); VIMALAKIRTI: 得無證三昧人中最為第一; SANSKRIT araṇā-vihāriṇām agryaḥ ?

bibl.title: 佛教語大辭典 Bukkyōgo daijiten Encyclopedic Dictionary of Buddhist Terms

sense.def: BUDDH: the perfection of concentration/mediation (one of the Six Perferctions of a Bodhisattva, liùdù 六度; see also chándìng 禪定); SANSKRIT dhyāna-pāramitā
BUDDH: type of samādhi: 'Wish-to-Know Samādhi' (in this state of concentration one has the ability to know everything what one wishes)

form.pron: fēng fèn xùn sān mèi mèi

bibl.title: 佛光大辭典 Fóguāng dàcídiǎn The Foguang Dictionary of Buddhism

sense.def: BUDDH: Wind-flying-quick Samādhi > 'Wheerl Wind Samādhi' (concentration in which one generates a violent wind which tears the body to pieces; see also fēng sānmèi 風三昧)

form.pron: fēi xiǎng fēi fēi xiǎng xiǎng
pɯl sqaŋʔ pɯl pɯl sqaŋʔ lʰiin
pɨi si̯ɐŋ pɨi pɨi si̯ɐŋ then

sense.def: BUDDH: state of neither perception nor non-perception, meditative state where there are no objects anymore, but still also no non-presence of objects. In the formless realm (wúsèjiè 無色界) this is the highest state and thus the highest form of existence in the three realms. However, a very subtle kind of thought is remaining and therefore this state is not identical with nirvāṇa; also referred to as the fourth heaven in the formless realm (see also 非想非非想處); skr. naiva-saṃj%nā-nāsaṃjnā-āyatana; PALI neva-sa%n%nā-nāsa%n%nā-āyatana

form.pron: fēng lún fèn xùn sān sān
plum ɡ-run pɯns sɯns saam mɯɯds
puŋ lʷin pi̯un sʷin sɑm muo̝i

sense.def: BUDDH: kind of samādhi (see 風三昧) (this samādhi mentioned in the text is probably a mix up of fēngfènxùn sānmèi 風奮迅三昧 and fēnglún sānmèi 風輪三昧)
